/COMMIT_MSG.message: I think Centos stream 9 seems to include etcd v3.4, and that should be taken into consideration. We need to ensure something in the defaults didn't change between 3.4 and 3.5 that will affect how the service runs under CS9
As discussed, i have modified the patch to use etcdv3.4 defaults suitable for CS9.

I haven't noticed any change in defaults between 3.4 and 3.5, except for these two parameters:

1. 'debug:false' deprecated in v3.5 and 'log-level:debug' is used instead.
https://etcd.io/docs/v3.4/op-guide/configuration/#--debug
https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/release-3.5/etcd.conf.yml.sample#L132

2  'self-signed-cert-validity: 1' introduced in v3.5
https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/release-3.5/etcd.conf.yml.sample#L129

We can use etcdv3.4 considering the support in c9, but we might have to eliminate/update these two parameters.

Adding several feedbacks I found while comparing the proposed implementation and puppet-etcd. Especially handling of the empty default would be the key difference and we better have careful review about these points.

Also, IIUC you are re-implementing the all interfaces in puppet-etcd but I'm wondering whether we can drop some. Implementing individual parameters completely is sometimes painful for maintenance(well, I know this eventually complains what I've done in Puppet OpenStack) because you need to update the parameter list timely. You can consider adding interfaces to inject additional definitions, such as etcd_conf_extra_opts/etcd_yml_extra_opts for let users customize anything they additionally.

Two things here:

1. The test for whether a variable is defined is definitely appropriate when the variable is defined outside of the current ansible role. But here we can rely on the tripleo_etcd_XXX variables being defined, because it's handled by this role's own defaults/main.yaml. In other words I think you can remove the "is defined" test for all tripleo_etcd_XXX variables.

2. This sort "|length" filter should only be necessary when the stuff inside of the conditional (i.e. L17) doesn't like empty values, and in this instance that is not the case. For one thing, this file contains a list of shell environment variables, and those can be blank (you cat set "MY_VAR=" and it will have an empty value.

Eliminated the j2 conditionals.

No! The ctlplane is only used by the undercloud when deploying the overcloud. There should be a way to use abstract names for the etcd service's hostname, ip, etc. Tripleo's "composable network" feature allows each service's network to be mapped (by Heat settings) to a physical network. For a simple standalone deployment, all of the services' networks are mapped to the ctlplane. For a larger deployment with network isolation, the etcd service should be using the internal_api network. The point is you cannot use a hard-coded physical network.

I guess we might want to fix the comments made for the cronie loop package install. But otherwise I think this looks good.

I know this is just a single package. But in general, I would avoid using loop with any of the package related Ansible modules. Each item in the loop is a new invocation of the package install process. So `dnf install package_1; dnf install package_2; dnf install package_3`. This is fairly inefficient, we're better of putting the list of packages directly into the name field, like they do in the example:
```
- name: Install the latest version of Apache and MariaDB
  ansible.builtin.package:
    name:
      - httpd
      - mariadb-server
    state: latest

```

Which gives you a single invocation of `dnf install http mariadb-server -y`

https://opendev.org/jjb/jenkins-job-builder/src/branch/master/tests/localyaml/test_localyaml.py#L33-L50 should support testing both examples that work and also ones that should cause an exception with the fixtures added under  https://opendev.org/jjb/jenkins-job-builder/src/branch/master/tests/localyaml/fixtures.

One alternative which comes to my mind is adding special yaml tag for this,
e.g. 'j2varsDict' or something, which would have custom loader calling to Jinja2Loader with param asking for the dictionary.

but seems to me there is no easy way how to get JJBConfig info into Jinja2Loader or at least be visible in local_yaml (quite few things would need to be changed?).

Another thing would be the name of the dict variable 'all_variables',
which could easily be problematic and colliding with existing usage,
so maybe some safer name (__all_vars__ or such?) could be better?

i wonder if reserved names should not be detected and warned about always - like in https://opendev.org/jjb/jenkins-job-builder/src/branch/master/jenkins_jobs/parser.py#L480 right after the .update() expansion is done.

jenkins_jobs/local_yaml.py.message:
Is it possible for `all_variables` to already exist and contain something different, in which case what would happen? e.g. someone defined it already as an input

Might be worth making sure that gets flagged or see if it can be exposed in another way here that won't shadow what is passed in.

I wonder if all_variables was a function that can return kwargs when called, so that in templates it has to be used 'all_variables()' would that automatically trigger an error if someone attempted overrode it or if at least the behaviour would not be surprising that trying to use 'all_variables()' when you've defined all_variables in your own templates to have it not work?

- switched to name 'jjb_variables'
- made it function (lambda)
- added error in case that name is already defined by user

Yes, I'd expect a function to still shadow, but was thinking that use of 'all_variables()' vs 'all_variables' might provide a useful hint as well as possibly calling 'all_variables' when it's now a function would cause an immediate error on parsing instead of leaving empty values for things might help.

I think probably the safest way would be to raise an exception with a useful message, if all_variables is already in use. Things prefixed '__' tend to indicate stuff that should be treated as private in python, where as I think this is intended to be used.

There maybe some additional debate on the actual name, whether it should use `jjb_variables` and then reserve anything prefixed with `jjb_` for future possible usage, changing the name should be a relatively simple find replace, so I wouldn't worry about that too much.

I'd recommend opting for the simple approach of whatever the name is, consider it reserved, with any usage of it being passed in to be considered an error and do the best possible to raise an exception when that is detected.

So currently 'all_variables' key contents gets replaced by 'kwargs'.
That is why I mentioned that this may not be the best name to use.

I do not see any easy way for doing it without possible collision:
- even when passed as function it would still override/overshadow the value expected by user
- it could be passed via 'globals', though then it is not expected to change (according to the docs, and then since template is 'cached' in _template and or there may be consequences if e.g. parallel rendering is attempted or such ... i would think it may not be the safest road to take)
- there might be way of using jinja2 extension though that seems quite complex (seems requires correctly handling jinja2 inner parser and AST is required, else "all kinds of compiler or runtime errors that are horrible to debug" - https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/3.0.x/extensions/#module-jinja2.ext so unless really desired i would prefer to avoid it)
- to me atm it seems it's leaving only the easier but less ideal possibilites:
-- using less-likely-to-overlap name (like __all_variables__ etc?)
-- issuing warning (or even error) when overlap is detected (we can easily check if 'all_variables' is present)
-- not injecting all_variables if presence is detected (as per point above, or can be combined with warning)
--- i believe this would practically work as if passing to globals - users value would be visible? (though maybe global values are procted
-- automatically selecting unused key (unpredictable or hardly, very likely to cause confusion)

This is why I was first thinking about config option to control this.


Alternative way possibly could be using the _template.environment.globals but injecting 'universal' helper function - as based on jinja2.contextfunction https://newbedev.com/how-to-get-a-list-of-current-variables-from-jinja-2-template - though that does include all resolvable names, including default jinja2 helpers and such, more then just the variables as passed from 'user-point-of-view' here in kwargs - and so may need filtering (as using the also injected helpers e.g. 'callable' in the linked article).

here you mean Nova instances ports, correct?
Yes, correct.
does this mean this server is also reachable from the internal network, 192.168.0.0/24 ?

The remote client can't reach it via the VPN. Even if all other client traffic is routed through the tunnel, the original route from the client to the VPN server has to remain, else the tunnel would collapse.

Nova instances on the internal network could reach the VPN server. I already use an OpenVPN hook to authenticate clients. It would be easy to refuse connections from the internal network, based on the client's IP.

the complex network topology scared me a bit.
even the remote client itself can reach this via the vpn, right?

Technically, yes, I think it is reachable (haven't actually tried it, though).

Of course it does not make much sense for a client already on the internal network to connect to it. Do you think there should be measures to prevent connections from such clients?
openvpn clients live in the external network and connect to 10.0.0.42 ?
Yes.
what sort of problems are you running into? How would listening in the internal port fix that?

Thinking about it, listening on the router's internal Port is also not a good solution.
The problem arises when the user sets up multiple vpn services in one router. The VPN servers need to listen somewhere. I see three options:
- Don't allow multiple VPN services in one router. This way, the VPN server listens on the router's external IP, openvpn's default port 1194.
- Have all VPN servers listen on the router's external IP, but on different ports. This would mean we need to explicitly configure the ports, and VPN clients need to be aware of this.
- Have the VPN servers listen on the router's internal IPs, using the default port. This would mean the VPN clients must be able to reach the internal network, i.e. have a route set up.
if you know the number of possible clients and it isn't huge, just having pre-created set of ports somehow associated to the vpn might be fine.
As discussed, we will favor Alternative 1. In this scenario, pre-created ports are also possible.
Seems simpler to me
Abandoning this option in favor of Alternative 1.
a user likely needs to tweak SG rules to accept this range, right?
is openvpn's dhcp service smart enough to avoid racing with neutron dhcp in the same l2 domain?

Good point. My expectation is a structure like this:

VPNClient <--> OpenVPN <--> tapdevice <--> internal network

I expect that openvpn's dhcp will only serve its clients, and their DHCP requests don't reach the internal network, and it would ignore DHCP requests from the internal network.

But I will have to check to confirm this.

@Sergii, other than allowing n-2 (which I don't ever recall that we supported that), your proposal is similar to mine. The primary difference seems to be requiring controller upgrade to latest CentOS. I'd be fine with writing the spec that way. Note that Wallaby already supports 8 and 9 today, that's why it seemed unnecessary to say that Wallaby controllers would only support 9. But, we can certainly drop support for 8 on controllers, or at least codify that we don't plan to maintain it.

The compute nodes have way less of software. Practically speaking I don't see a way to separate OS upgrade on controller nodes. The complexity will be a way too high to test all possible scenarios and possible software. I am thinking about partners with own products based on TripleO. Will they make upgrade paths?

I'd say we can
1) Upgrade Undercloud with new CentOS. (1 machine or 1 VM)
2) Upgrade Controllers with CentOS. (3 machines or 3 VMs)
3) We may upgrade containers only on Compute nodes (5-1000 machines) to newer version and separate OS upgrade on these machines. It's a different approach to hybrid mode where we allowed n-2 nova computes to talk to latest nova api. 

This approach will allow to finish upgrade within maintenance window leaving OS upgrade on computes for different maintenance windows. It should be a good compromise allowing to an upgrade path with good quality.

Actually, we may be able to re-use my own "hack": TCIBception:
https://github.com/cjeanner/tripleo-tools/tree/main/container-build

it builds the container images from within a container; meaning: we can build whatever version we want on whatever host we have - cs9 containers on cs8, the reverse, or even from a Fedora node (I mostly tested that latter matrix - fc-35 node building cs8/cs9 containers for master and wallaby).

it's not really a feature - more of a usage? But if you want TCIB to actually run the container-in-container build, it may be something. Though I'm afraid it would make the overall code over-complicated in the end. We can of course discuss this, there are pros and cons, as usual :).

Basically, my thing:
- pulls the correct centos stream version container image
- generate a bootstrap script for the container
- starts the container with the correct mounts/ENV and command

Then, the script mainly:
- does some repository management (enable CRB and HA when needed)
- reinstalls tzdata (its content is removed at CS container build time)
- installs correct ansible (ansible on cs8, ansible-core on cs9)
- installs some ansible collections (mainly tripleo-operator-ansible)
- generates an ansible playbook

The ansible playbook:
- fetches and installs latest tripleo-repos (via the operator)
- gets the needed info for the actual container build (DLRN hash, for instance)
- runs the TCIB command with the correct params (via the operator)
- cleans everything within the container to not explode the disk usage (podman rm -af, podman rmi -af, and so on).

So it's a 3-stages ugly bunch of lines, but it works.

Not sure this can be embedded in TCIB itself - unless we kind of wrap things? That would require a huge code refactoring though, not sure it's worth the effort, since we can get an external code for that.. ?

The Upgrade team is trying to implement the spec as-is with the intention of getting OpenStack Upgraded and then upgrading the Undercloud & Controllers in a separate step. The hope is to upgrade as many containers as possible to the UBI9 version in the first step, so I do not think it is necessary to continue building *all* the containers on both versions.

The notion of 'what is supported' has two parts:

1. What is possible via code.
2. What we are prepared to support on a running Cloud.

I think we should keep the options open in code (ie item 1) to allow flexibility as we go from version to version. Item 2 is something that any organisation using TripleO can decide downstream on a per-version basis.

From the item 2 perspective, we certainly do not intend to support a running cloud Control Plane running the new version on the older operating system. The ability to run it that way is intended only as a step towards upgrading the Operating System.

The benefit of this is that we are able to break down a hug monolithic and very complex action (upgrading the control plane) into two, less complicated steps. This is good for the Operator and good for us because it's easier to troubleshoot and easier to test.

I guess it doesn't really matter. The main thing would be that we need to continue to build el8 and el9 containers for everything. Whereas if we focus on computes, we can limit it to a more as needed basis for things like OVN and libvirt. For example, if we take a basic compute node with standard services:
```
[heat-admin@overcloud-compute-0 ~]$ sudo podman ps --format {{.Names}}
nova_virtlogd_wrapper
nova_virtsecretd
nova_virtnodedevd
iscsid
nova_virtstoraged
nova_virtqemud
nova_virtproxyd
nova_migration_target
logrotate_crond
ovn_controller
ovn_metadata_agent
nova_compute
nova_virtlogd
neutron-haproxy-ovnmeta-acefae53-b4d5-422f-bcca-dc32a0785d21
neutron-haproxy-ovnmeta-4fba0b6e-a031-4d7e-948a-c6d7035ee2e4
```

We don't really need all of them to have host dependent versions. It's only ovn_controller and nova_virtqemud, maybe nova_virtnodedevd. So I guess the decision we need to make is, "Are we doing this for every single container on a el8 host?" So regardless of the service, if the host is el8 should we use only ubi8 containers, even for things like logrotate_crond? 

Or, should we do it on a as required basis for host dependent binaries like OVN and qemu. 

The latter option probably requires less concern for CVE's and would give the cloud more consistency. While the former is probably an easier problem to solve for. We just need to always build both versions of all containers which isn't a huge amount of effort. 

I guess Controllers are the same minus the libvirt dependency. But maybe we want to enforce the OS version of controllers since we would have more control over the overall platform stability and predictability. Whereas allowing the Compute nodes to run different versions accommodates scenarios where application vendors require el8 hypervisors for their application.

(Giving -1 to highlight my question)

Here we are a bit between the two models -- one that uses release candidates to do a single release (cycle-with-rc), and the one that does multiple full releases (cycle-with-intermediary).

I personally think cycle-with-intermediary is a better match for what you are doing, since you are not using RCs.
If you are not using RCs it feels like the release model should be updated to cycle-with-intermediary (like it was in Yoga) ?
The hashes are all OK, my concern is only the versions (see my comment inline).

If that suit the current plan then I'm ok with changing it.

In the past we used cycle-with-interediary and created release per milestone but we agreed with creating a single release per cycle. When we made that switch, I changed the release model from cycle-with-intermediary because my understanding was that the previous model requires at least one intermediate release during a cycle but that might be wrong.
I would prefer if we updated the model back to cycle-with-intermediary as it is closer to what's being done here. But we can do that as a separate change imho

If this is really aimed to be an RC1 release and later on goes out as Final versions, then I guess cycle-with-rc is the right model for Puppet OpenStack. But that is maybe just my opinion.

Here we intend to release GA rather than RC1(because we didn't create explicit release we created rc1 release in the past), so I modified the commit message to mention GA rather than RC1. We probably can create rc1/ga following the other projects but that's not what we have done in the past releases. AFAIK "rc" release is not generally done in Puppet modules so I tend to keep the existing release model (directly create GA without rc).

Focus on the issue here, that is that the L3 routing is done in the kernel, via iptables. So you can summarize this saying this: "In the ML2/OVN DVR implementation, the L3 routing is executed in the kernel, using iptables. That means the OpenFlow datapath is broken before the packet is delivered to the network interface. The performance degradation affects specially to OVS-DPDK".
Is it mandatory to use "openvswitch"? Could be used with "noop"?
Instead of VIMP, I would used the term "FIXEDIP", that is commonly used in Neutron to refer to a local IP in a private network.
The local router IP?

This section (and the next one) is describing the POC you probably have. But this is not necessary. What we need to have in a spec is a description of *what* are you going to do, not *how* in the code. What I was expecting from this spec:
- An overall description of the feature.
- A description of the type of flows/traffic types that will be affected (ARPs, ICMP, etc). That is done but in different sections.
- Also could be fine to have a graph of the flow of these traffic types.

We don't need here what new methods are going to be added and their descriptions.

nodepool/builder.py.message: You can change the last group to "(?:\w+)" which makes it a non-capturing group.  Then you can omit the _ below.

This is getting pretty close to a "style nit" which we don't normally go for in code review, but I think this can be simplified in a way that makes it much easier to maintain, so I hope you'll indulge me.  If you do this (i'm abbreviating some things slightly and assuming the regex change above):

seen = set()
for entry in scandir:
  m = match(entry.name)
  if m:
    name_and_id = m.groups()
    if name_and_id in seen: continue
    seen.add(name_and_id)
    yield name_and_id

nodepool/driver/static/provider.py.message: Do we also need to remove the node from the _node_slits[nodeTuple(static_node)] list to avoid reprocessing it over and over again?

In both cases where this method is called, it's shortly after getRegisteredNodes is called, so the _node_slots list will have been updated.  It should either contain the correct data, or possibly some extra slots from a max-parallel-jobs reduction which hasn't been able to be contracted yet for some reason (possibly the node was locked when the reduction happened).  If we get to this point with an extra slot, we will try to deregister the ZK node, then if that succeeds, the next time we call getRegisteredNodes the _node_slots will be updated and will no longer have the extra slots.

Put another way, the sequence is this:
1. Update node_slots to represent the union of config and zookeeper
2. Attempt to remove extra nodes in node_slots from zookeeper

And we always call the method that does step 1 (getRegisteredNodes) before step 2 (syncNodeCount or _start).
Similar question as above. I think this may end up retriggering over and over again since deregisterNode(node) only updates the zk record?
The same is true as above.
The empty line should stay IMO, it separates library modules from external ones.
The empty line separated concurrent.futures.thread and collections, and aren't both of those external libraries? Making the empty line is not necessary according to me

We generally try to separate imports as described, but we also try to avoid changing things that don't need changing, and we try to avoid commenting on whitespace changes in reviews.  They should almost never be considered a -1.

At any rate, collections is in the standard library, so this change is fine.

Renaming the argument seems unrelated and makes it more difficult to see what this patch is actually doing. If you think that the rename is necessary, I would prefer to see it split out into a dedicated patch.
The name "static_node" and "node" have important distinctions.  This helps the developer understand that we're dealing with a config object and not a zk object.  This should stay in the change.

static_node seems to be a common name throughout nodepool/driver/static/provider.py, because of this i believe it makes sense to rename it here as well. However, I can agree that it is not directly related to this change's topic.

Do we need to set node.slot to idx here? In particular entries to unslotted_nodes may have node.slot set to None accordingto the else at line 179. Additionally, if a slot shifts somehow we'd need to reconcile that?

That is an option, but I don't think we need to do that.  Node.slot==None should only happen in the case where we upgrade, so the actual slot number of the node isn't that important.  The next time the node is (re)created, it will get a slot number assigned to it, and things will be good from there.  Actually assigning the slot here would be fairly complex because we would need to lock the node, and it may already be locked.  Instead, the approach is to just have it occupy any slot in memory until it's gone.  From the consumer's (zuul's) pov, it wasn't created with a slot, so it will just be None.
See above though I think it would be node.slot = len(node_slots[nodeTuple(node)]) - 1

ironic/drivers/modules/irmc/common.py.message:
So validate was always more about not actually connecting to the BMC, but about attempting to validate sufficient information was present to connect in the first place.

Could storage of the BMC version and connection to the BMC to validate the snmp hash version be a bit excessive? Is there a good reason to do so? Why does the "Try this, fail with an appropriate error" not work flow wise?

Regarding the complexity of the code (getting the BMC version to check the protocol each time), at first I was worried that the iRMC version would be updated during the process, so I chose to get the latest value every time. 

However, since in practice we would never update the BMC in the middle of the process, and even if the protocol was supported, it would fail again if it didn't match the actual configuration, so I agree with you that this code is too complicated.  Furthermore, the cause of communication failure due to wrong protocol can be identified from the error message when actually performing SNMP communication. 

Therefore, I will change the code to not check if the value is supported or not, and return an appropriate error message if communication failure happens like you said.

sriov-fec-operator-images/files/0001-pat.message: Please provide some explanation in the commit message why this fix is necessary.

Is this related to the need for the vfio-pci params to have the 'sriov enabled' param specified (which we don't do today but have a work item to do).  Just wondering if this is a temporary fix in this commit

The way Smart Edge implemented the validation for the vfio-pci driver command line parameters is not correct. This has to be fixed properly. Until then this is a temporary fix. when SmartEdge fixes it, we will remove this change. Indeed, there is no need for this check, it is a pre-requisite to set those parameters for vfio-pci in order to use in vfio mode (i.e., binding PF interface with vfio-pci driver) which platform should take care of before deploying the operator. If the vfio-pci driver's enable_sriov parameter is not set, operator will fail to apply cluster config in vfio mode irrespective there is a check or not. We will work with Intel/SmartEdge team to either fix it to check in proper way or remove this check condition.

specs/victoria/approved/glance/duplicate.message: This is not valid according our current plan.
can add at least me here.

Do we need to describe what is the chunk size, is it configurable?

How much waiting time for next chunk? what happens while waiting if original image is deleted?

Also at the moment we have dependency of glance-cache-manage tool to delete cached images, so we need to modify delete operation as well.

We also need to mention that upon upgrade cache needs to be cleaned before using this new behavior (new upgrade check).

> Do we need to describe what is the chunk size, is it configurable?

I'd rather not make it configurable at least initially like discussed during the PTG session. I think the choosing the right chuk size needs bit of experimenting but somewhere around 500MB-1GB should be sufficient.
 > 
 > How much waiting time for next chunk? what happens while waiting if
 > original image is deleted?

How long is piece of string? So obviously this depends how well the store performs, how utilized and fast the networks are etc. If we decide to keep the chunk size around or below a gig, I wouldn't expect wait times averaging more than few seconds between chunks even in busy systems. The client doesn't need to even know that we're waiting. As long as we stay below any tcp connection timeouts (which is by default 60 seconds, I think). The client just sees small pause on the data stream, which is by spec and gets naturally handled in the connection control. We do not send "chunks" to the client but uniform datastream like we do currently, we just combind the cached chunks from the disk so this is transparent to the client.

I think if you currently delete image while it's downloading the downloads will fail and that will continue to be the case.
 > 
 > Also at the moment we have dependency of glance-cache-manage tool
 > to delete cached images, so we need to modify delete operation as
 > well.

Yes, the work item 2 is to make sure that the driver cache methods are modified to be able to deal with the chunked caching.
 > 
 > We also need to mention that upon upgrade cache needs to be cleaned
 > before using this new behavior (new upgrade check).

This is not necessary with the simplified chunked caching where we do not combine the cache to single file at the end. (That part was removed from the plans due to the complexity and i/o-load it causes without real benefits.)

Well the reading logic will need to be tweaked anyways to be able to serve the images for those requests that came when the caching was in flight. That means not doing it is not causing any extra work, just simplifying and keeping the I/Os under control.

specs/zed/approved/glance/duplicate-down.message: Suppose that during download, the image is deleted.  Then the caching will fail, and you will get a failed download for the original + all subsequent requests (as you should), but note that you have used up a lot of network bandwidth for no purpose.  Why not block on subsequent requests until you know that the download to the cache will succeed, instead of reading chunks as they become available?

Well, it's not just deletion; same thing will happen if the download to the cache is interrupted or something.  It's fine if we want to regard that as a low-likelihood occurrence, I'd just like to see something in the spec saying that we considered the issue and rejected it.

I guess the main point is that if you're going to boot 1K instances, you should make sure the image is cached before you do the boot.  On the other hand, since the cache is local to each glance node, that won't do an end user any good (assuming we're willing to expose the cache contents (or maybe only the images accessible to the end user making the request)) unless they know the cloud topology, i.e., which glance serves the computes where they want the instance build to land.
As Mridula kindly pointed out, this approach is listed 2nd at the Alternatives section already. Is that enough as indication it was considered?

Maybe I'm not reading carefully enough, but with the exception of the config option, Alternative #2 sounds exactly like what you're proposing here ... especially the part that says "It comes at the cost of all downloads occurring while an image is being cached depending on that single cache to be successful. This means a cache failure could result in more clients needing to retry, potentially after waiting for nearly the entire image to download", which I take it is the reason why Alternative #2 was an alternative and not the proposed change when the spec was originally written.  So I think you do need to explain why you are OK with accepting this tradeoff.

I have few reasons in mind why not to, but lets be realistic here. How often you expect this to happen? How often did you see people deleting their images before they got their instances up and running from it when you were part of operating public cloud? I can't recall a single occurence from my times that would have came to our attention, but you were part of much bigger deployment.

I think the reasoning for caching in general is to speed up the boot process, not to slow it down. Based on your experience is what you proposed there common and big enough issue to make the trade off?

Purely techincal; delaying the requests introduces another can of worms I'm not sure we do want to open. We would need to have some keepalive introduced in case caching the full image takes longer than our timeouts are for the request.

How would we communicate to the user that their operation is delayed because we have cache enabled?

I see your proposal only addressing if the image is deleted while we're caching it, not if it's deleted while we are serving it from cache (iirc delete will clean it from cache too, failing the inflight requests again), so should we hold on that request forever or just fail all downloads to start with? That would save all the bandwidth 😜

Also wondering how much extra complexities the "hold up" code would potentially bring and how would we track those connections.

I also wonder what happens currently if we get two connections that are both attempting to tee-cache the file, and the *second* one is terminated by the client. I suspect maybe the first one will continue writing to the deleted file, but the one left by the second cacher will be left on the filesystem, incomplete. If the first one marks the image as cached in the sqlite DB, but does not realize its file on disk is not the actual one left reachable in the directory by the terminated second cacher, will we think we have a cached image that is in fact partial?
This is explained better at line #104

From what I've read here, I don't see the correlation between the chunking and the subsequent readers grabbing from the in-progress cache. If there's some dependency there, can you point it out?

The same thing can be done with a single file, and without needing to introduce the complexity of the "is this whole or is this in pieces" handling for the cache readers. Splitting the cached file into chunks may be useful for resuming interrupted cache operations, but it seems like that is separate from the proper handling of multiple concurrent cache operations. IMHO, it would be a lot better to split this effort into those two pieces and attack them separately, to reduce the amount of change to the caching stuff that we have to digest and validate for acceptance.

This was discussed briefly in the PTG session, but I think that it would be good to outline here your plans for:

1. How do you wait?
2. Do you poll for new data/chunks? How often?
3. How long before you decide that the original cacher is dead?
4. What do you do in case of #3? Try to resume from backend or fail?
I think it's likely that clients (human, at least) might abort if they see no data after a minute or two, assuming it's never coming. So yeah, this doesn't seem like a viable alternative to me.

I think it's worth mentioning in this section that (unless I'm missing something above), there is an increased likelihood of failed image downloads with this mechanism, because if there are N clients downloading the same image and the first one aborts, it will take out the rest of them after some timeout. Today (IIUC) the others will continue and likely succeed, albeit at the cost of speed and bandwidth.

this is mainly a nit, but this is a bit weird to read since you are declaring provider_geometry inside the if/elif clauses and returning it outside. It is not wrong because there are only 3 choices, but it makes it harder to maintain in the future if either this logic or the config option should change.

My suggestion: Since default is 512e, use if and elif for 512 and 4k, and use else for setting provider_geometry to the dict respective to 512e.

I decided to unextract this code back into the initialize_connection function, it's not too long and makes the function more obvious about what it's actually doing. In doing so, it solves this concern I think. Hopefully that sounds OK to you.
you will always return something in self._get_geometry, this condition is not required.

I think it would be better to just note that 4k native can cause compatibility and performance (alignment) issues with some software and operating systems and not refer to the Microsoft KB article.

It's a decent article but it's full of information that's Windows-specific and not really relevant to Cinder admins in general.

We have other drivers that support 4k sectors and they don't dive into all of this -- maybe there should be something about it in the general Cinder doc?

All in all, it's nice - but I'd like to understand the rationale behind exposing unauthenticated exporters on a separate network vs scraping Kolla-Ansible deployed Prometheus server.

Commit message is vague, no release note attached - hard to understand the motive.
I think a better solution is just to scrape the prometheus server - there's a patch for exposing it here: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/828695

But in the case you have an external tool monitoring Openstack's cloud, deploying Prometheus server wouldn't make much sense, since I'm allocating resources when I already have my monitoring program doing the same job. In this case, I think it would be more suitable to expose the exporters, also the feature is not forcing you to expose the exporters if you don't want to.

> But in the case you have an external tool monitoring Openstack's cloud, deploying Prometheus server wouldn't make much sense, since I'm allocating resources when I already have my monitoring program doing the same job. In this case, I think it would be more suitable to expose the exporters, also the feature is not forcing you to expose the exporters if you don't want to.

Any updates on this?

The reason for this change it's that you could have an external tool monitoring Openstack's cloud status. Therefore, we wouldn't want to allocate servers resources deploying Prometheus since you already have an external monitoring system doing the same job.

Regardless of this, I acknowledge that leaving those exporters unauthenticated represents a security risk. Do you have any suggestions that can help us solve this issue?
Any updates on this?

There are no principal changes, just ability to use different network.

plugins/modules/stack_info.py.message: Is this actually true? You seem to be setting 'name' in the call to orchestration.stacks, which I don't think would actually look up by ID.

Good catch!

Unfortunately we cannot implement filtering by ID that easy: openstacksdk does not pass id as a query param (even though the Heat API does support it). Its search_stacks() function does accept any query args, so filtering would always be done on clientside. Using find_stack would require us to implement the clientside filtering on our (aoc) side. None of those solutions is good..

..which is why I simply dropped the 'or ID' part from the docs, like it was before.
